quiz.name: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 6 Session 2
quiz.subtopic: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 6 Session 2
instructions:
CFA Level 1 Mock Exam Instructions

This CFA Level I mock exam (Session 2) is in English and contains 90 multiple-choice questions. You will have 2 hours and 15 minutes to complete the exam and review your answers. 

Before You Begin

Please note the following in regards to this examination:

  • International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) apply unless otherwise noted.
  • "The Code" refers to the CFA Institute Code of Ethics.
  • "The Standards" refers to the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct.
  • "GIPS® standards" refers to the Global Investment Performance Standards.

How to Answer Questions

  • Each question is numbered and includes multiple-choice options (lettered A, B, C).
  • For each question:
    • Decide which answer is best.
    • Select the corresponding letter.
    • Click 'Next' to move to the next question.
  • You may:
    • Select only one answer per question.
    • Skip questions or return to questions by selecting the ‘Previous’ or the ‘Next’ buttons.

After Completing the Exam

  • Click 'Submit' when you are finished.
  • Once submitted, you may review all questions and your selected answers.
  • Only selected responses will be scored.
  • Your score will reflect the number of correct answers only.
    • No penalty for incorrect answers.
    • It is to your advantage to answer every question, even if you are unsure of the correct answer.
  • If you finish early, use the remaining time to review questions you are unsure about.

Click the 'Begin' button when you are ready to start the mock exam.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05846
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about three companies and their common shares:

  Company 1 Company 2 Company 3
Market price per share $34 $12 $56
Book value of shareholders' equity (in millions) $452 $302 $98
Number of shares outstanding (in millions) 45 105 12

Which company has the lowest price-to-book value per share?

answerFeedback.435a6756-74a7-42be-8084-ab9d115e33a9: Incorrect because Company 3's P/B = $56 / ($98 / 12) ≈ 56 / 8.1667 ≈ 6.857, which is higher than Company 1's P/B of 3.385. However, a candidate might select this based on the fact that it has the lowest book value of shareholders' equity ($98 million).
answerFeedback.6ad52ad9-9734-48eb-96e3-0dae9fb55b2f: Incorrect because Company 2's P/B = $12 / ($302 / 105) ≈ 12 / 2.876 ≈ 4.172, which is higher than Company 1's P/B of 3.385. However, a candidate might select this if they incorrectly select Company 2 based on the fact it has the lowest book value / share (2.876).
answerFeedback.892f627d-b270-4ef9-810b-98a0ff8ef9ce: Correct because price to book value per share (P/B) = Market price per share / (Book value of shareholders' equity / shares outstanding). In Company 1's case, P/B = $34 / ($452 / 45) ≈ 34 / 10.044 ≈ 3.385.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Alts-Roberts-09
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is an example of an event-driven hedge fund strategy?

answerFeedback.108155ba-7e2b-438e-9c77-f3f246e0a1a0: Incorrect because it describes an equity market neutral strategy. Market neutral strategies use quantitative (technical) and fundamental analysis to identify under- and overvalued equity securities. Hedge funds take long positions in securities they have identified as undervalued and short positions in securities they have identified as overvalued.
answerFeedback.3c30622e-a2b1-4501-8e9d-e82585feffe9: Correct because it describes a special situations investment strategy, a type of event-driven investing. Special situations strategies focus on opportunities to get involved in the equity of companies that are engaged in restructuring activities other than mergers, acquisitions, or bankruptcy. These activities include security issuance or repurchase, special capital distributions, rescue finance, and asset sales/spin-offs.
answerFeedback.85cdbbf5-6ead-4135-b9e2-05ab5fa8450c: Incorrect because it describes a relative value (short volatility) strategy. Relative value funds seek to profit from a pricing discrepancy, an unusual short-term relationship, between related securities. A short-volatility strategy (a type of relative value strategy) involves selling options to earn the premiums and benefit from calm markets but can experience significant losses during unexpected periods of market stress.

choices.itemBody: A. Buying the stock of a company that is spinning off a subsidiary
B. Selling stock options to earn premiums and benefit from limited market movements
C. Taking long positions in undervalued stocks and short positions in overvalued stocks

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Johnson-01
entry.itemBody: Contracts entered into at one point in time that require both parties to engage in a transaction at a later point in time on terms agreed upon at the start are called:

answerFeedback.42cf69fa-31db-47ed-939c-fe3fa46b01b0: Correct because forward commitments are contracts entered into at one point in time that require both parties to engage in a transaction at a later point in time (the expiration) on terms agreed upon at the start.
answerFeedback.9dd91252-32eb-41d1-bf61-afb113d6246a: Incorrect because a contingent claim is a derivative in which the outcome or payoff is dependent upon the outcome or payoff of an underlying asset. Although this characteristic is also associated with forward commitments, a contingent claim has come to be associated with a right, but not an obligation, to make a final payment contingent on the underlying.
answerFeedback.e7aa8858-bc0a-4d1d-bfac-ab3897cb41b8: Incorrect because an option contract (which is also referred to as a contingent claim), is a derivative in which the outcome or payoff is dependent upon the outcome or payoff of an underlying asset. Although this characteristic is also associated with forward commitments, a contingent claim has come to be associated with a right, but not an obligation, to make a final payment contingent on the underlying. Given that the holder of the contingent claim has a choice, the term contingent claim has become synonymous with the term option.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05345
entry.itemBody:
A portfolio manager creates the following two-security portfolios:

Security Security Weight Expected Standard Deviation
A 30% 30%
B 70% 25%

If the correlation of returns between the two securities is 0.60, the expected standard deviation of the portfolio is closest to:

answerFeedback.0ec11740-2a73-4e8c-81fd-5575ecf7544a:
Incorrect because it uses standard deviation instead of variance in the first part of the equation and did not take the square root

σ p o r t ≠ w 2 1 σ 1 + w 2 2 σ 2 + 2 w 1 w 2 σ 1 σ 2 ρ 1 , 2  =

(0.3)2(0.30) + (0.7)2(0.25) + 2(0.3)(0.7)(0.60)(.30)(.25) =

(0.027) + (0.1225) + (0.0189) =

0.16815 = 16.8%.
answerFeedback.41dd80e1-0a81-4293-b103-4d6a4b1345d8:
Correct because 

σ p o r t = w 1 2 σ 1 2 + w 2 2 σ 2 2 + 2 w 1 w 2 ρ 1 , 2 σ 1 σ 2  =

σ port = ( 0.3 ) 2 ( 0.30 ) 2 + ( 0.7 ) 2 ( 0.25 ) 2 + 2 (0.3) (0.7) (0.6) (0.30) (0.25)  =

σ p o r t = ( 0 . 09 ) ( 0 . 09 ) + ( 0 . 49 ) ( 0 . 0625 ) + 0 . 0189  =

σ p o r t = 0 . 057625  = 0.240052078 = 24.0%.
answerFeedback.c0c32134-95bc-4dfa-88ae-bd03e5193339: Incorrect because it is simply the weighted average standard deviation. 0.30(0.3) + 0.70(0.25) = 0.265, or 26.5%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Huffman-02
entry.itemBody: With respect to an IPS, which of the following best describes a relative risk objective for the client's portfolio?

answerFeedback.056a0ff0-92ae-491b-bf72-5d1c6e62e23b: Correct because for risk relative to a benchmark, the measure could be tracking risk, or tracking error. Further, an expected tracking risk of 2% would imply a return within 4% of the index return approximately 95% of the time. Remember that tracking risk is stated as a one standard deviation measure.
answerFeedback.b73d238f-cca6-4083-82ee-e8a331c3747c: Incorrect because maintaining cash is an IPS constraint, not a risk objective.
answerFeedback.df7b97e1-8353-4f47-9640-5d645dabcf8e: Incorrect because measures of absolute risk include the variance or standard deviation of returns and value at risk. For example, the 12-month 95% value at risk of the portfolio must be no more than ¥1 billion.

choices.itemBody: A. An annual tracking risk of less than 2 percent
C. Maintaining at least €10,000 in cash for planned monthly withdrawals

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Glover-01
entry.itemBody: A mutual fund that does not have a sales charge to purchase or redeem shares in the fund is best described as a(n):

answerFeedback.556e0997-b767-4548-9fa7-b2618a7ff753: Incorrect because the decision on a fund's load (the charge for purchasing or redeeming shares) is separate from the decision on whether it is an open-end or closed-end fund. The fund can be set up as an open-end fund or a closed-end fund. If it is an open-end fund, it will accept new investment money and issue additional shares at a value equal to the net asset value of the fund at the time of investment. An open-end fund can be either a load or a no-load fund.
answerFeedback.8a9450dd-4c63-420e-a530-b603e8fca185: Incorrect because an exchange-traded fund is not classed as a mutual fund. Exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are investment funds that trade on exchanges (similar to individual stocks) and are generally structured as open-end funds. While ETFs are structured similarly to open-end mutual funds, some key differences exist between the two products.
answerFeedback.c3d77b4c-a243-4ec7-b212-72167fcbbc24: Correct because, in addition to open-end or closed-end funds, mutual funds can be classified as load or no-load funds. The primary difference between the two is whether the investor pays a sales charge (a 'load') to purchase, hold, or redeem shares in the fund. In the case of the no-load fund, there is no fee for investing in the fund or for redemption but there is an annual fee based on a percentage of the fund's net asset value.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607113
entry.itemBody:
Using the following information and assuming coupons are paid annually, the G-spread of the Steel Co. bond is closest to:

Bond Maturity Coupon Price
Steel Co. 2 Years 5.00% 101.70
Treasury bond 2 Years 4.00% 100.50

answerFeedback.14e1643f-0b69-4d6b-997f-ce0e7b27d496: Incorrect because it is calculated as coupon rate difference: 5% – 4% = 1%.
answerFeedback.918d9834-f7ec-48d6-8001-7bafdadc3de6: Incorrect because it is calculated as current yield difference: (5/101.70) – (4/100.50) = 4.9164% – 3.9801% = 0.9363%, i.e., 94 bps.
answerFeedback.bf219299-00c2-4a97-9f35-22385d289d96:
Correct because the yield for the Steel Co. bond is calculated as

5 ( 1 + r ) + 5 + 100 ( 1 + r ) 2 = 101.70

r = 4.0974 %

The yield for the Treasury bond is calculated as

4 ( 1 + r ) + 4 + 100 ( 1 + r ) 2 = 100.50

r = 3.7359 %

G-spread is calculated as the yield difference between the Steel Co. Bond and the Treasury bond: 4.0974% – 3.7359% = 36.15%, or 36 bps.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Deriv-Fang-04
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements regarding forward contracts is most accurate?

answerFeedback.7e01b49b-c3ca-42a9-9da8-2f013b8b6962: Correct because the value of a forward contract is the spot price of the underlying asset minus the present value of the forward price. As the spot price of the underlying increases, so does the value of the long forward contract.
answerFeedback.bd1a8498-a70b-4e5f-81c4-c8c2e8fc6adf: Incorrect because the forward price is the spot price compounded at the risk-free rate over the life of the contract, not the risk premium.
answerFeedback.c4501f9f-4b7b-4fc2-8e55-0a765e15f500: Incorrect because, at expiration, the value to the short party is the forward price minus the spot price at expiration.

choices.itemBody: A. The value of a short forward contract is the spot price minus the forward price at expiration
B. The value of a long forward contract increases as the spot price of the underlying increases
C. The forward price is the spot price compounded at the risk premium over the life of the contract

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09661
entry.itemBody: Which of the following features of an established hedge fund is most likely designed to allow orderly liquidation of positions to meet redemptions?

answerFeedback.84b35957-bb04-487a-80c0-c2cf0e41ad30: Incorrect because lockup periods, time periods when investors cannot withdraw their capital, provide the hedge fund manager the required time to implement and potentially realize a strategy’s expected results. The hedge fund is already experiencing redemptions and thus, although a lockup period may help at the margin by delaying some redemptions that would otherwise need to be funded, a notice period for redemptions is more likely to assist the hedge fund manager to liquidate positions in an orderly manner.
answerFeedback.8f773a34-7784-4679-916a-a472a5cd94a3: Correct because notice periods provide an opportunity for the hedge fund manager to liquidate a position in an orderly fashion without magnifying the losses.
answerFeedback.c06acb78-6b93-4576-a0b9-32b3624f3fcb: Incorrect because funds sometimes charge redemption fees (typically payable to the remaining investors) to discourage redemption and to offset the transaction costs for remaining investors. The hedge fund is already experiencing redemptions and thus, although a redemption fee may help at the margin by offsetting costs, a notice period for redemptions is more likely to assist the hedge fund manager to liquidate positions in an orderly manner.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Elkinawy-Young-13
entry.itemBody: The type of index weighting system in which a stock split on one constituent security changes the weights on all the securities in the index is:

answerFeedback.033c0eaf-84bd-4500-bccf-fc841138be77: Correct because a property unique to price-weighted indexes is that a stock split on one constituent security changes the weights on all the securities in the index.
answerFeedback.7efc5635-bb15-4211-ab04-85d94391f77f: Incorrect because this is a characteristic associated with a price-weighted index. A stock split would not change the relative weight of a security in a value-weighted index since the total market value of the security would be unchanged after the split. In market-capitalization weighting, or value weighting, the weight on each constituent security is determined by dividing its market capitalization by the total market capitalization (the sum of the market capitalization) of all the securities in the index. Market capitalization or value is calculated by multiplying the number of shares outstanding by the market price per share.
answerFeedback.837a9fe6-07f6-4e04-97fa-74c65c927de2: Incorrect because this is a characteristic associated with a price-weighted index. An equal weighted index is rebalanced when its constituent securities’ prices change in order to maintain equal-weighting. After the index is constructed and the prices of constituent securities change, the index is no longer equally weighted. Therefore, maintaining equal weights requires frequent adjustments (rebalancing) to the index.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06525
entry.itemBody: For European options, all else being equal, a higher exercise price results in a higher value for:

answerFeedback.185beed8-cb45-433c-94e9-2f415d5aea3b: Incorrect because higher exercise price results in a higher value for puts only (not calls), as explained in the rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.26e2b142-a725-4bc3-aca8-21fd96a45372: Correct because the value of a European call option is inversely related to the exercise price whereas the value of a European put option is directly related to the exercise price. Therefore, all else being equal, the higher the exercise price, the higher is the value of European puts and the lower is the value of European calls.
answerFeedback.b4814000-c8fe-4dc1-a8be-19846f73029d: Incorrect because higher exercise price results in a higher value for puts only (not calls), as explained in the rationale for the correct answer.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-29
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, which of the following factors is most likely associated with a narrowing corporate bond yield spread?

answerFeedback.13d1ac98-ff44-4167-80ae-d228d1eded71: Correct because greater demand for bonds relative to supply are associated with narrower yields. In periods of heavy new issue supply, credit spreads will widen if there is insufficient demand. In periods of high demand for bonds, spreads will move tighter.
answerFeedback.1dd7c959-fd97-4bd5-8212-f08dca1e24d6: Incorrect because weakening economic conditions will push investors to desire a greater risk premium and drive overall credit spreads wider.
answerFeedback.f882dfb1-bb31-4737-9030-12ae15b3112b: Incorrect because a negative earnings release by the issuer is associated with a widening of corporate bond yield spreads. Good news increases the attractiveness of buying and holding bonds issued by the corporation, which raises bond prices and narrows spreads; bad news will have the opposite effect.

choices.itemBody: B. A negative earnings release by the issuer
C. Greater market demand for bonds relative to supply

entry.title: ITEM_20170601019
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is least likely one of the main benefits of derivative markets? Derivative markets:

answerFeedback.07583b94-cd2d-4356-aa62-bd1f582ef89d: Correct. Derivative markets are not necessarily more or less volatile than spot markets. And excessive risk taking and use of leverage in derivative markets may contribute to market stress.
answerFeedback.2efbada1-54f9-4774-8ee7-a6563e1da486: Incorrect. One of the main purposes of derivative markets is risk management
answerFeedback.a30b50da-159e-414b-8dcb-d58d61709742: Incorrect. One of the main purposes of derivative markets is price discovery.

choices.itemBody: A. reveal prices and volatility of the underlying assets.
B. exhibit lower volatility compared with the spot market.
C. enable companies to more easily practice risk management.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516027
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements regarding indexes for alternative investments is most accurate?

answerFeedback.33f98a01-b500-4023-b558-db599cc37e81: Correct. Hedge fund companies are not required to report their performance to any party other than their investors. As a result, rather than index providers determining the constituents, the constituents determine the index.
answerFeedback.6d0fb207-dd9f-4fa9-af91-1b2aa73b6a1b: Incorrect. Commodity indexes are based upon futures contracts, not prices of the underlying commodities themselves.
answerFeedback.9e92dd38-2503-438e-a7ff-24774f1f5d93: Incorrect. Commodity indexes consist of futures contracts. There is no market weighting mechanism.

choices.itemBody: A. Hedge funds determine whether their results will be included in an index.
B. Commodity index returns are based on changes in the prices of the underlying commodities
C. Commodity indexes consist of a market-weighted basket of one or more specific commodities

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.06-Alt-Hambusch-06
entry.itemBody: Privately held convertible debt is most likely used by companies in which of the following life cycle stages?

answerFeedback.a98d1836-e631-45f2-8a8e-468ba979b939: Incorrect because privately held convertible debt is relied on in the seed or start-up stages of the corporate life cycle, not in the maturity stage.
answerFeedback.b0b49074-636e-4b2f-af1c-16ed795675dd: Incorrect because privately held convertible debt is relied on in the seed or start-up stages of the corporate life cycle, not in the growth stage.
answerFeedback.d8c31199-1cea-4496-b5a9-d12633cae962: Correct because privately held convertible debt is relied on in the seed or start-up stages of the corporate life cycle.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10671
entry.itemBody: With respect to risk-adjusted return measures, the information ratio is calculated as Jensen's alpha divided by a security's:

answerFeedback.695bf321-9821-4913-8412-8be08be1ccac: Correct because the information ratio for a security is Jensen's alpha divided by nonsystematic variance. The information ratio, (i.e., alpha divided by nonsystematic risk), measures the abnormal return per unit of risk added by the security to a well-diversified portfolio. The larger the information ratio is, the more valuable the security.
answerFeedback.91b84d9f-0838-4b63-b9a6-26fb03162e38: Incorrect because the information ratio for a security is Jensen's alpha divided by nonsystematic variance, not systematic variance.
answerFeedback.b880376d-2de6-49ce-874d-6dc7b25f6103: Incorrect because the information ratio for a security is Jensen's alpha divided by nonsystematic variance, not total variance.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Deriv-Young-01
entry.itemBody: Which of the following derivative contracts has a hard commodity underlying?

answerFeedback.65ab84f2-2c19-4d44-914d-7af34d9594c4: Incorrect because cattle futures are an example of a derivative contract with a soft commodity underlying. Soft commodities are agricultural products, such as cattle and corn.
answerFeedback.6a214846-a258-4689-b595-7af53d009ed8: Correct because aluminum futures are an example of a metals contract, which is a derivative with a hard commodity underlying.
answerFeedback.fa91d937-c449-4955-b562-f2d704040aa9: Incorrect because soybean options (and futures) are an example of a derivative contract with an agricultural, or soft, commodity underlying.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Loo-10
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is an exclusive feature of private equity funds as opposed to hedge funds?

answerFeedback.038d0f86-2678-4c1e-a619-d158e622f934: Incorrect because the partnership agreement usually specifies that the performance fee is earned only after the fund achieves a return known as a hurdle rate. The hurdle rate is a minimum rate of return. Hurdle rates are less common for hedge funds but do appear from time to time.
answerFeedback.7dfba706-1803-4676-a676-91fa7a7f06c7: Incorrect because on top of the management fee, a performance fee (also referred to as an incentive fee or carried interest) is applied based on excess returns. The partnership agreement usually specifies that the performance fee is earned only after the fund achieves a return known as a hurdle rate. The hurdle rate is a minimum rate of return. Hurdle rates are less common for hedge funds but do appear from time to time. As for hedge fund managers, they generally accrue an incentive fee on their quarterly performance, but they typically crystalize (realize) their incentive fee once annually.
answerFeedback.ebcf343e-4fc4-46f6-95f5-0248e55ecbc5: Correct because the management fee is typically based on committed capital, not invested capital; the committed-capital basis for management fees is an important distinction from hedge funds, whose management fees are based on assets under management (AUM).

choices.itemBody: C. Management fees based on committed capital

entry.title: ITEM_20170516154
entry.itemBody:
An investor evaluating a company’s common stock has gathered the following information:

Current dividend per share $2.40
Dividend growth rate expected during Years 1 to 2 20%
Dividend growth rate expected from Year 3 onward 4%
Company’s WACC 13%
Required rate of return on equity 15%

The intrinsic value per share of this common stock is closest to:

answerFeedback.18ff5326-cea8-4b77-a921-e964651bb258:
Correct because using the two-stage dividend discount model:

V0 = D 1 ( 1 + r ) 1 + ⋯ + D n ( 1 + r ) n + P n ( 1 + r ) n

V0 = intrinsic value of a stock

Dt = expected dividend in year t

r = required rate of return on the stock

Dt = Current dividend per share = $2.40

V0 = 2.40 ( 1.20 ) 1.15 + 2.40 ( 1.20 ) 2 1.15 2 + 2.40 ( 1.20 ) 2 ( 1.04 ) ( 0.15 − 0.04 ) × 1 1.15 2

= $2.50 + $2.61 + $24.71 = $29.82
answerFeedback.a1444e28-edf0-44b7-a838-782d6ab8d007:
Incorrect because it uses incorrect computations for D1, D2, and D3 by making mistakes in accounting for time periods.

V = 2.40 1.15 + 2.40 ( 1.20 ) 1.15 2 + 2.40 ( 1.20 ) ( 1.04 ) ( 0.15 − 0.04 ) × 1 1.15 2

= $2.09 + $2.18 + $20.59 = $24.86
answerFeedback.acb94422-2801-4d6c-b319-f964bbab639c:
Incorrect because the terminal value at the end of Year 2 is discounted with n = 3 instead of n = 2.

V = 2.40 ( 1.20 ) 1.15 + 2.40 ( 1.20 ) 2 1.15 2 + 2.40 ( 1.20 ) 2 ( 1.04 ) ( 0.15 − 0.04 ) × 1 1.15 3

= $2.50 + $2.61 + $21.48 = $26.59

entry.title: ITEM_20180516051
entry.itemBody: For parallel shifts in the benchmark yield curve, key rate durations indicate the same interest rate sensitivity as:

answerFeedback.71fe5740-745d-4af2-bdec-5226daddccb6: Incorrect because modified duration is a yield duration (rather than a curve duration) statistic that does not measure a bond’s sensitivity to a change in the benchmark yield curve.
answerFeedback.974bcaee-a63b-44f3-b4fe-48a80446e413: Correct because for parallel shifts in the benchmark yield curve, yields at all maturity segments of the curve move the same in both direction and magnitude and the curve maintains its shape (no flattening or steepening). As a result, key rate durations at all maturity segments will indicate the same interest rate sensitivity as effective duration, the measure of interest rate risk in terms of a parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve.
answerFeedback.f3a8d649-266d-4fb3-a4cd-dc79692b8537: Incorrect because Macaulay duration is a yield duration (rather than a curve duration) statistic that does not measure a bond’s sensitivity to a change in the benchmark yield curve.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10758
entry.itemBody: Adding alternative investments to a portfolio of traditional investments most likely increases portfolio:

answerFeedback.0018ee1b-840b-4a31-8c3e-445893bf69c5: Incorrect because fund investment structures for alternative investments differ substantially from traditional public equity and fixed-income fund or ETF investments. For example, alternative funds usually involve less frequent transparency on periodic returns and fund positions versus equity or fixed-income funds.
answerFeedback.664530d5-5a97-4e5c-a6b3-1fe668403697: Correct because investors often consider alternative investments in pursuit of greater portfolio diversification.
answerFeedback.e7f09bad-e8f3-4e9f-9d64-2f83cae66216: Incorrect because investors are often attracted to alternative investments when seeking greater diversification and/or higher expected returns in exchange for what are often longer-term, illiquid investments in less efficient markets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Gundlach-15
entry.itemBody: The binomial option pricing model always:

answerFeedback.4de79543-8765-4ee1-af8b-c8a26e0c973b: Incorrect because, while the binomial model does enable the construction of a risk-free hedge consisting of the option and the underlying, the appropriate ratio needs to be calculated. One needs to derive the number of units of the underlying that will perfectly hedge one unit of the short call, and one unit of each is not the appropriate balance.
answerFeedback.590eaad3-8d2e-462a-bf20-2c3e051b321a: Correct because the binomial model requires knowledge of what the upside case is (represented by S1+) and what the downside case is (as represented by S1–). We cannot arbitrarily set these values at just anything. We will be required to know the values of S1+ and S1–.
answerFeedback.6efbc6b9-0752-40c1-a1d0-2042010aa4f6: Incorrect because the actual probabilities of the up and down moves do not matter.

choices.itemBody: A. requires knowledge of the magnitude of possible up and down moves.
B. requires knowledge of the actual probabilities of possible up and down moves.
C. enables the construction of a risk-free hedge consisting of one unit of each of the option and the underlying.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FI-Groenning-13
entry.itemBody: A mortgage pass-through security most likely has:

answerFeedback.35b66cc4-5f64-4d4a-ac0d-c0a737180cad: Incorrect because the monthly cash flows of a mortgage pass-through security are less than the monthly cash flow of the underlying pool of mortgages by an amount equal to the servicing and other administrative fees. The cash flows of a mortgage pass-through security depend on the monthly cash flows of the underlying pool of mortgages. The amount and the timing of the cash flows from the pool of mortgages cover both the cash flow passed through to the security holders and administrative charges for servicing the pool. These administrative charges include collecting monthly payments from borrowers, forwarding proceeds to owners of the loan, sending payment notices to borrowers, maintaining records of the outstanding mortgage balance, initiating foreclosure proceedings if necessary, and providing tax information to borrowers when applicable. Additionally, the issuer or financial guarantor of the mortgage pass-through security may charge fees for guaranteeing the issue. All these fees are typically calculated as a portion of the mortgage rate.
answerFeedback.5d108eff-e29b-4544-81d3-c49b1ad4f6ca:
Correct because prepayments for fixed-rate mortgages will vary depending on interest rates. When interest rates decline, actual prepayments will be higher than forecasted because homeowners will refinance at lower interest rates. Mortgage refinancing is particularly common in the US given the absence of loan prepayment penalties, which are more prevalent in other countries. Thus, the maturity of an MBS will be shorter than what was anticipated at the time of purchase. Contraction risk is the risk that the borrower repays the principal or a portion of the principal in a shorter period of time than the contractually agreed scheduled payment, reducing the amount of future payments the investor receives. For investors, this has two adverse consequences. First, investors must reinvest the proceeds at lower interest rates. Second, the prepayment option reduces the potential price appreciation for the bond.
When interest rates increase, actual prepayments will be lower than forecasted because homeowners will become less likely to refinance their mortgages and may even delay new home purchases. Thus, the maturity of an MBS will be longer than what was anticipated at the time of purchase. Extension risk is the risk that the borrower repays the principal or a proportion of the principal in a longer time period than the contractually agreed scheduled payment. For investors, this has adverse consequences: Higher interest rates reduce the value of the cash flows investors receive. Therefore, payments the investors receive will be discounted at a higher interest rate, and the extension stretches out the payments the investors receive.
answerFeedback.90d59b13-0b92-4fd4-a221-bdcb113e1db0: Incorrect because the investors in these securities receive the principal and interest payments from the assets (often loans) in the pool as they are “passed through” the legal entity. Pass-through securities pass through the payments proportionally across the different tranches and redistribute the payment risks to investors seeking differing levels of risk exposures. The payments investors receive vary and depend directly on the overall credit risk of the pool and payment patterns.

choices.itemBody: C. greater cash flows than the underlying pool of mortgages.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Berlinicke-22
entry.itemBody: The price value of a bp for a 30-year, 1% annual coupon payment bond with a par value of €1,000 and a yield to maturity of 0.8% is closest to:

answerFeedback.5bbc3efd-a192-406c-8a6b-4ff5f5375ab9:
Incorrect because the 1 bp is wrongly multiplied with the 30-year tenor of the bond and the par value:

PVBP = 30 × 0.01% × 1,000 = 3.00.
answerFeedback.bd75f672-344b-401a-9a24-cc95af384c43:
Correct because:

PVBP = [(full price calculated by lowering the yield-to-maturity by 1 bp) – (full price calculated by raising the yield-to-maturity by 1 bp)] / 2

PVBP = (1,055.90 – 1,050.42) / 2 = 2.74,

whereby PV–: FV = 1,000; PMT = 10; N = 30; I/Y = 0.79%; CPT PV = 1,055.90 and

PV+: FV = 1,000; PMT = 10; N = 30; I/Y = 0.81%; CPT PV = 1,050.42.
answerFeedback.be152c8c-e9a9-40f8-9906-081398184b08:
Incorrect because the 1 bp reduction and increase is wrongly applied to the coupon rate, not the yield-to-maturity:

PVBP = (1,002.58 – 997.42) / 2 = 2.58,

whereby PV–: FV = 1,000; PMT = 10; N = 30; I/Y = 0.99%; CPT PV = 1,002.58 and

PV+: FV = 1,000; PMT = 10; N = 30; I/Y = 1.01%; CPT PV = 997.42.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Lin-07
entry.itemBody: Based on put-call parity, a fiduciary call can be created by combining:

answerFeedback.1547b201-a52c-4a29-ab57-3504ccb8465d: Incorrect because a fiduciary call is not equal to a long call and a short risk-free zero-coupon bond.
answerFeedback.9741e5a1-180e-4596-9c26-62513e870d77: Incorrect because a fiduciary call is not equal to a short put and a long risk-free zero-coupon bond.
answerFeedback.eca990ad-3d74-4b5f-989a-1ec405d6afd9: Correct because a fiduciary call is equal to a long call and a long risk-free zero-coupon bond.

choices.itemBody: A. a long call and a long risk-free zero-coupon bond.
B. a short put and a long risk-free zero-coupon bond.
C. a long call and a short risk-free zero-coupon bond.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Grabe-10
entry.itemBody: The Gordon growth model assumes that the dividend growth rate is:

answerFeedback.3634cb0b-d59a-4393-97d8-82dd23075ba6: Incorrect because one of the assumptions of the Gordon model is: The dividend growth rate is strictly less than the required rate of return.
answerFeedback.67d74ec5-e0ba-4910-afdd-3b876202ac50: Correct because one of the assumptions of the Gordon model is: The dividend growth rate is strictly less than the required rate of return.
answerFeedback.bc6d9ea5-0b1e-4dbe-ba50-3ffd65e20150: Incorrect because one of the assumptions of the Gordon model is: The dividend growth rate is strictly less than the required rate of return.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the required rate of return.
B. equal to the required rate of return.
C. greater than the required rate of return.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06419
entry.itemBody: When calculating portfolio duration as the weighted average duration of individual bonds, an analyst implicitly assumes that the yield curve:

answerFeedback.0329faa5-698d-482a-bfa6-7575c4fe562e: Correct because the Macaulay and modified durations for the portfolio are calculated as the weighted average of the statistics for the individual bonds. The shares of overall portfolio market value are the weights. This measure of portfolio duration implicitly assumes a parallel shift in the yield curve. Therefore, portfolio duration is the best measure of the interest rate risk of a bond portfolio when there is a parallel shift in the yield curve.
answerFeedback.e194491e-f443-4db1-9a44-40f47a164297: Incorrect because portfolio duration implicitly assumes a parallel shift in the yield curve. In reality, interest rate changes frequently result in a steeper or flatter yield curve. Therefore, portfolio duration is the best measure of interest rate risk of a bond portfolio when there is a parallel shift in the yield curve, and not when the yield curve steepens.
answerFeedback.ec2db2be-3be6-49f7-a4c8-fcda5d0feb03: Incorrect because this measure of portfolio duration implicitly assumes a parallel shift in the yield curve. In reality, interest rate changes frequently result in a steeper or flatter yield curve. Therefore, portfolio duration is the best measure of interest rate risk of a bond portfolio when there is a parallel shift in the yield curve, and not when the yield curve flattens.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FI-Pitrakkou-02
entry.itemBody: If interest rates are increasing, the effective duration of a bond with an embedded put option is:

answerFeedback.75837bbb-7eda-4751-bfb6-1bd0273f2a03: Incorrect because an embedded put option reduces the effective duration of the bond, especially when rates are rising.
answerFeedback.7c7a6854-847a-44ab-8e3d-e409e77250c9: Correct because an embedded put option reduces the effective duration of the bond, especially when rates are rising.
answerFeedback.f375d2e3-9f71-45fd-a129-d07400426c8f: Incorrect because an embedded put option reduces the effective duration of the bond, especially when rates are rising.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the effective duration of an option-free bond.
B. the same as the effective duration of an option-free bond.
C. greater than the effective duration of an option-free bond.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607109
entry.itemBody: Which of the following embedded options most likely provides a right to the issuer of a bond?

answerFeedback.44091bd6-5bb7-43f7-96a6-f5d7aac08f4c: Incorrect because the right to put the issue is an option granted to the bondholder to sell the bond back to the issuer at a predetermined price on specified dates before maturity.
answerFeedback.8e1ec914-30b4-46b1-a335-7ac8640b10dd: Correct because the right to call the issue is beneficial to the issuer when interest rates fall.
answerFeedback.cdaf739e-6fad-475d-b657-3a863633c083: Incorrect because the conversion provision grants the bondholder the right to convert the bond for a specified number of shares of common stock. Such a feature allows the bondholder to take advantage of favorable movements in the price of the issuer’s common stock.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Huffman-01
entry.itemBody: According to portfolio theory, combinations of the risk-free asset and a risky asset result in:

answerFeedback.58cbfcfa-ac1c-4fc6-84b0-baba0e59a608: Correct because the combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset can result in a better risk–return trade-off than an investment in only one type of asset because the risk-free asset has zero correlation with the risky asset. The combination is called the capital allocation line.
answerFeedback.77e1f127-8a7a-4c77-a4f5-a8dbce67a671: Incorrect because the curve that lies above and to the right of the global minimum-variance portfolio is referred to as the Markowitz efficient frontier because it contains all portfolios of risky assets that rational, risk-averse investors will choose. That is, the Markowitz efficient frontier only contains risky assets, while the capital allocation line is a combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset.
answerFeedback.e627adba-d7ff-4807-8acd-872888f47346: Incorrect because the capital allocation line (CAL), not the investor's indifference curve, is the combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset. An indifference curve plots the combinations of risk–return pairs that an investor would accept to maintain a given level of utility (i.e., the investor is indifferent about the combinations on any one curve because they would provide the same level of overall utility). Indifference curves are thus defined in terms of a trade-off between expected rate of return and variance of the rate of return. Because an infinite number of combinations of risk and return can generate the same utility for the same investor, indifference curves are continuous at all points.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607115
entry.itemBody: If the annual market discount rate is 6%, the value of a 3-year bond that has a 7% coupon rate, has a maturity (par) value of $1,000, and pays interest annually is closest to:

answerFeedback.74ea2822-9ef6-4ec6-8ffc-dcce5dde1ba6: Incorrect because the answer is $1,026.73. ($1,049.17 is derived by doubling the number of payments to 6, as if the bond were making semi-annual payments rather than annual.)
answerFeedback.87852d52-5c65-4e09-a5bd-9f9478549515: Incorrect because the answer is $1,026.73. ($973.76 is calculated by reversing the coupon rate and discount rate.)
answerFeedback.8b45d3e2-d4a0-4edb-8f44-b322cf942c04:
Correct because

PV = PMTt / (1+r)t, where

PV is the present value

PMT is the payment = par value × coupon rate = $70

r is the market discount rate.

Expanding this equation over three years results in a present value equal to:

$70 1.06 1 + $70 1.06 2 + $1,070 1.06 3 =$66.04+$62.30+$898.39=$1,026.73

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06079
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is an underlying assumption of yield to maturity as a measure of expected return for a bond?

answerFeedback.74dbd98d-4f3f-4852-b9ca-7c7986c5d09f: Incorrect because although one of the assumptions of yield-to-maturity as a return measure is that there is no default by the issuer, it only assumes that the issuer does not default, meaning all interest and principal payments are made as scheduled. Although a change to the credit rating of the issuer may change the market price of the bond before maturity, the return measure is yield to maturity, meaning principal repayment is par at maturity, and credit ratings in the interim or at maturity will not impact that amount.
answerFeedback.a6705894-a525-41e5-94b8-dfacda160232: Correct because the yield-to-maturity at the time of purchase measures the investor's rate of return under three assumptions: (1) The investor holds the bond to maturity, (2) there is no default by the issuer, and (3) the coupon interest payments are reinvested at that same rate of interest.
answerFeedback.fb858bf0-bae4-4db3-a0be-c5d645a5d675: Incorrect because the yield-to-maturity at the time of purchase measures the investor's rate of return under three assumptions: (1) The investor holds the bond to maturity, (2) there is no default by the issuer, and (3) the coupon interest payments are reinvested at that same rate of interest. The assumptions require the bond to be held to maturity, not to be sold at the purchase price.

choices.itemBody: A. The credit quality of the issuer remains the same
B. The bond is sold at the same price as the purchase price
C. Coupons are reinvested at the same rate as the yield to maturity at purchase

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Young-04
entry.itemBody: Which of the following measures is an example of a top-down driver for forecasting a firm’s revenue?

answerFeedback.8b5f5a6b-44e3-4bbc-b1c5-598ed3bbac5d: Incorrect because examples of bottom-up drivers for revenue forecasts include the following: Volumes and average selling prices.
answerFeedback.e8a5bb32-c567-4e2c-a810-7653c57dc7da: Incorrect because same-store sales growth is an example of a capacity-based measure which is a bottom-up forecast object. Examples of bottom-up drivers for revenue forecasts include capacity-based measures. Forecasts, for example, in retailing, based on the number of stores and sales per store, or same-store sales growth (for stores that have been open for at least 12 months) and sales related to new-store openings.
answerFeedback.f0c15f38-43da-41f6-84a5-eac4f338ebf2: Correct because growth relative to GDP growth is an example of a top-down forecast object. Common top-down forecast objects include 'growth relative to GDP growth' and 'market growth and market share.'

entry.title: ITEM_20170601058
entry.itemBody: Which of the following attributes is least likely to be a requirement for the existence of riskless arbitrage? The underlying security:

answerFeedback.743a5844-28be-4c80-a17d-3e5659900ba9: Incorrect because for riskless arbitrage to exist, the underlying security must be relatively liquid so it is easy to buy and sell at a low cost.
answerFeedback.a1c70d52-3152-4d92-b701-8a6d291baeba: Incorrect because for riskless arbitrage to exist, the underlying security must be able to be short sold.
answerFeedback.fa7beb17-396b-446b-beca-9384594e07f3: Correct because riskless arbitrage can exist when the underlying security that can be arbitraged is either a financial or a non-financial security.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Mazur-01
entry.itemBody: Returns adjusted for the total risk of a portfolio relative to a benchmark are most appropriately measured using which of the following?

answerFeedback.5a3f6f8d-7d36-44d8-b657-ee6cdca146cf: Incorrect because the Treynor ratio is a simple extension of the Sharpe ratio and resolves the Sharpe ratio’s first limitation by substituting beta (systematic risk) for total risk.
answerFeedback.a2f0df4f-d9e4-4b49-b373-95f0ada4bdaa: Incorrect because Jensen's alpha is based on systematic risk. Performance measures relative to beta risk—Treynor ratio and Jensen’s alpha—are relevant when the investor holds a well-diversified portfolio with negligible diversifiable risk.
answerFeedback.fe771abd-8689-4866-a83f-dacea3513bc4: Correct because M2 provides a measure of portfolio return that is adjusted for the total risk of the portfolio relative to that of some benchmark. Total risk is relevant for an investor when he or she holds a portfolio that is not fully diversified, which is not a desirable portfolio. In such cases, the Sharpe ratio and M2 are appropriate performance measures.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607124
entry.itemBody: A bond is currently selling for 102.31. A valuation model estimates the price will fall to 101.12 if interest rates increase by 20 bps and rise to 103.74 if interest rates decrease by 20 bps. Using these estimates, the effective duration of the bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.28fafff8-3543-4e78-8276-2945eb2e68b5:
Incorrect because it has 103.74 in the denominator instead of 102.31:

103.74−101.12 2×103.74×0.002 =6.31
answerFeedback.d7949e1b-85d2-4379-b595-fc48fedbe9fb:
Correct because the effective duration of a bond is

EffDur = ( P V − )−( P V + ) 2×( ΔCurve )×( P V 0 ) where PV–, PV0, and PV+ are the values of the bond when the yield falls, under the current yield, and when the yield rises, respectively, and ΔCurve is the change in the benchmark yield curve.

EffDur = 103.74−101.12 2×102.31×0.002 =6.40
answerFeedback.e0a0f445-b7f1-4c25-81c2-b025c29f361a:
Incorrect because it has 101.12 in the denominator instead of 102.31:

103.74−101.12 2×101.12×0.002 =6.48

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Tsependa-07
entry.itemBody: Which of the following cognitive errors is best classified as a processing error?

answerFeedback.288d1493-b24c-40a9-84e2-d76a9a5a657a: Incorrect because it is a belief perseverance bias, and not a processing error. The belief perseverance biases discussed are conservatism, confirmation, representativeness, illusion of control, and hindsight.
answerFeedback.7de192f7-5570-43b7-bea9-02bf1f919e3e: Correct because the processing errors discussed are anchoring and adjustment, mental accounting, framing, and availability. Anchoring and adjustment bias refers to relying on an initial piece of information to make subsequent estimates, judgments, and decisions.
answerFeedback.8981e45f-c9d9-4ff8-bd22-03db8dfba0a8: Incorrect because it is a belief perseverance bias, and not a processing error. The belief perseverance biases discussed are conservatism, confirmation, representativeness, illusion of control, and hindsight.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03129
entry.itemBody: A bond issued by the International Monetary Fund is best classified as a:

answerFeedback.15676f61-f403-49f4-80a1-79757eb50e41: Incorrect because sovereign bonds are issued by national governments. National governments issue bonds primarily for fiscal reasons—to fund spending when tax revenues are insufficient to cover expenditures. Bonds issued by national governments, are often referred to as sovereign bond or sovereigns.
answerFeedback.8f27013a-22d6-433f-b06e-95549c253b54: Correct because supranational bonds are a form of often highly rated bonds issued by supranational agencies, also referred to as multilateral agencies. The most well-known supranational agencies are the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (the World Bank), and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
answerFeedback.d166262c-1348-47c0-bfb7-4cfbe8f530cc: Incorrect because quasi-government bonds are issued by entities established by national governments to perform various functions. These organizations often have both public and private sector characteristics, but they are not actual governmental entities.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427078
entry.itemBody: A hedge fund with $225 million of initial capital charges a management fee of 1% and an incentive fee of 10%. The management fee is based on assets under management at year-end, and the incentive fee is calculated independently from the management fee. Assuming the fund earns a 15% return at year-end, total fees earned by the hedge fund during the year are closest to:

answerFeedback.6d6cf07d-b86c-4f4f-8586-e39f84c74afe:
Incorrect. $5.70 million represents the total fees earned if the incentive fee was calculated net of the management fee as opposed to independently from the management fee:

Year-end value = $225 million × 1.15 = $258.75 million

Management fee = Year-end value × Management fee %

= $258.75 million × 1% = $2.5875 million

Incentive fee = (Year-end value – Beginning value – Management fee) × Incentive fee %

= ($258.75 million – $225 million – $2.5875 million) × 10% = $3.1163 million

Total fees = Management fee + Incentive fee

= $2.5875 million + $3.1163 million = $5.7038 million = $5.70 million
answerFeedback.6fabc7aa-0ece-478c-ab83-b807c3616537:
Incorrect. $5.63 million results from calculating the management fee based on assets under management at the beginning of the period, rather than the end of the period:

Year-end value = $225 million × 1.15 = $258.75 million

Management fee = Beginning value × Management fee %

 = $225 million × 1% = $2.25 million

Incentive fee = (Year-end value – Beginning value) × Incentive fee %

 = ($258.75 million – $225 million) × 10% = $3.375 million

Total fees = Management fee + Incentive fee

 = $2.25 million + $3.375 million = $5.625 million = $5.63 million
answerFeedback.769582c4-1999-4e7b-9b4a-0032e6c027e4:
Correct. Total fees earned by the hedge fund are closest to $5.96 million:

Year-end value = $225 million × 1.15 = $258.75 million

Management fee = Year-end value × Management fee %

= $258.75 million × 1% = $2.5875 million

Incentive fee = (Year-end value – Beginning value) × Incentive fee %

= ($258.75 million – $225 million) × 10% = $3.375 million

Total fees = Management fee + Incentive fee

= $2.5875 million + $3.375 million = $5.9625 million = $5.96 million

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Vervloet-10
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate?

answerFeedback.2d265a89-58ee-4294-9279-e825c01407ef: Correct because LPs play passive roles and are not involved with the management of the fund (although co-investment rights allow for the LPs to make additional direct investments in the portfolio companies); the operations and decisions of the fund are controlled solely by the GP.
answerFeedback.5ee125a7-2204-427a-96c9-f5f814e791e6: Incorrect because the partnership between the GP and LPs is governed by a limited partnership agreement (LPA), a legal document that outlines the rules of the partnership and establishes the framework that ultimately guides the fund’s operations throughout its life. In addition to LPAs, side letters may also be negotiated. Side letters are side agreements created between the GP and a certain number of LPs that exist outside the LPA.
answerFeedback.cc6af116-5252-4a03-91ee-0d4dafe0feec: Incorrect because in the world of alternative investments, partnership structures are common. In limited partnerships, the fund manager is the general partner (GP) and investors are the limited partners (LPs). LPs, who are generally accredited investors (owing to legal restrictions on the fund), are expected to understand and be able to assume the risks associated with the investments, which are less regulated than offerings to the general public. The GP runs the business and theoretically bears unlimited liability for anything that goes wrong.

choices.itemBody: A. The general partner theoretically has limited liability
B. Co-investment rights allow the limited partner to make additional direct investments in portfolio companies
C. The side letter is a legal document that outlines the rules of the partnership between the general partners and all limited partners

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FI-Moustra-07
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about covered bonds is most accurate?

answerFeedback.24a2b503-4d25-4a77-b635-806650e02fc2: Correct because whereas ABS often use credit tranching to create bond classes with different borrower default exposures, covered bonds usually consist of one bond class per cover pool.
answerFeedback.ddc6fb74-644e-40d0-8c60-bb9c10c52293: Incorrect because in contrast to a static pool of mortgage loans that expose investors to prepayment risk as in the case of US mortgage-backed securities, cover pool sponsors must replace any prepaid or non-performing assets (i.e., assets that do not generate the promised cash flows) in the cover pool to ensure sufficient cash flows until the maturity of the covered bond.
answerFeedback.f8065c9c-2e6e-4bbe-a5b1-6069da874649: Incorrect because in the case of ABS, the financial institution that originates loans transfers securitized assets to a bankruptcy-remote special legal entity, but the pool of underlying assets in a covered bond (or “cover pool”) remains on the financial institution’s balance sheet, against which covered bondholders retain a top-priority claim.

choices.itemBody: A. Covered bonds expose investors to prepayment risk.
B. Covered bonds usually consist of one bond class per cover pool.
C. The cover pool is transferred to a bankruptcy-remote special legal entity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04299
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a float-adjusted market-capitalization-weighted index composed of three stocks:

Stock Shares Outstanding % of Shares in Market Float Price
1 8,500 100 $42
2 10,000 75 $69
3 4,000 100 $95

Stock 1's weighting in the index is closest to:

answerFeedback.09081957-0521-42db-b290-3069751d8c61:
Incorrect because it fails to take into account the float-adjustment:

Market-cap weight = market cap / sum of all market caps in index

= 42 × 8,500 / (42 × 8,500 + 69 × 10,000 + 95 × 4000)

= 357,000 / (357,000 + 690,000 + 380,000) = 357,000 / 1,427,000 ≈0.25 = 25.0%.
answerFeedback.2383a65a-cb33-4f26-8aa4-181ea6786469:
Incorrect because it is the price-weighted weight:

Price weight = price / sum of all prices in index

= 42 / (42 + 69 + 95) = 42 / 206 = ≈ 0.204 = 20.4%.
answerFeedback.4750aca4-9684-44c2-8c2c-2be9a522a8a2:
Correct because Stock 1's float-adjusted market-capitalization weighting is calculated:

= Float-adjusted market capitalization / sum of all float-adjusted market caps in index

= 42 × 8,500 × 100% / (42 × 8,500 × 100% + 69 × 10,000 × 75% + 95 × 4000 × 100%)

= 357,000 / (357,000 + 517,500+ 380,000) = 357,000 / 1,254,500 ≈ 0.285 = 28.5%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Hu-01
entry.itemBody: A trader bought shares for $20 per share at an initial margin of 40%. If the maintenance margin is 20%, the price below which the first margin call occurs is:

answerFeedback.4fffc8b8-b238-4e93-a34c-2d24fdce7342: Incorrect because it calculates the margin call price to be: (1 – 0.4)/(1 + 0.2) × $20 = $10.
answerFeedback.5ae52cf6-508f-463e-b046-b63541f8fc5a:
Correct because initial margin = $20 × 40% = $8. 

When the final price of the stock is P, the change in trader's equity = $8 + (P – $20) = (P – $12). 

For a margin call to happen, total equity per share / total price per share = (P – $12)/P < 20 % (maintenance margin). Hence P < $15.
answerFeedback.b0cea884-ecc1-407d-b911-e8ac4736689c:
Incorrect because it uses 20% for initial margin instead of 40%.

Initial margin = $20 × 20% = $4, and it calculates the margin call price to be $20 – $4 = $16.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Deriv-Simsek-12
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about zero rates:

Years to Maturity Zero Rate
1 1.50%
2 2.00%
3 2.25%

The 2-year implied forward rate in one year's time is closest to:

answerFeedback.257ddf99-ce98-4f99-9e85-af4b2ff17aa3:
Incorrect because this is the implied forward rate zero-coupon bond that starts in year 2 and ends in year 3 with a tenor of 1 (= 3 – 2) year, denoted with IFR2,1, whereas what is being asked is IFR1,2. The general formula for the relationship between the two spot rates (zA, zB) and the implied forward rate (IFRA,B–A) that starts in period A and ends in period B is given by (1 + zA)A × (1 + IFRA,B–A)B–A = (1 + zB)B

Therefore, for the provided information:

(1 + z2)2 × (1 + IFR2,3–2)3–2 = (1 + z3)3, 

(1 + 2%)2 × (1 + IFR2,1)1 = (1 + 2.25%)3, 

IFR1,2 ≠ IFR2,1 = (1 + 2.25%)3/(1 + 2%)2 – 1 = 0.027518 ≈ 2.75%
answerFeedback.649a0d77-c4be-40c6-82ff-34aed5e64529:
Incorrect because this is the implied forward rate that starts in year 1 and ends in year 2 with a tenor of 1 (= 2 – 1) year, denoted with IFR1,1, whereas what is being asked is IFR1,2. The general formula for the relationship between the two spot rates (zA, zB) and the implied forward rate (IFRA,B–A) that starts in period A and ends in period B is given by (1 + zA)A × (1 + IFRA,B–A)B–A = (1 + zB)B

Therefore, for the provided information:

(1 + z1)1 × (1 + IFR1,2–1)2–1 = (1 + z2)2, 

(1 + 1.5%)1 × (1 + IFR1,1)1 = (1 + 2%)2, 

IFR1,2 ≠ IFR1,1 = (1 + 2%)2/(1 + 1.5%)1 – 1 = 0.025025 ≈ 2.50%
answerFeedback.c30f5481-28c1-4bb1-9af8-2e074b6b8c49:
Correct because this is the implied forward rate that starts in year 1 and ends in year 3 with a tenor of 2 (= 3 – 1) years, denoted as IFR1,2. The general formula for the relationship between the two spot rates (zA, zB) and the implied forward rate (IFRA,B–A) that starts in period A and ends in period B is given by (1 + zA)A × (1 + IFRA,B–A)B–A = (1 + zB)B

Therefore, for the provided information:

(1 + z1)1 × (1 + IFR1,3–1)3–1 = (1 + z3)3, 

(1 + 1.5%)1 × (1 + IFR1,2)2 = (1 + 2.25%)3, 

IFR1,2 = [ (1 + 2.25%)3/(1 + 1.5%)1]1/2 – 1 = 0.026271 ≈ 2.63%

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03052
entry.itemBody: If a portfolio consists of two risky assets and the portfolio's standard deviation is equal to the weighted average of the assets' standard deviations, the assets' returns are:

answerFeedback.0b22a8f4-cdb8-4400-bfd2-c68b8cb50f80:
Correct because portfolio risk is unaffected when the two assets are perfectly correlated  or ρ12 = +1, the portfolio standard deviation is:

 

σp = ω21σ21 +ω22σ22 + 2ω1ω2σ1σ2

In other words, the portfolio's standard deviation is simply a weighted average of the standard deviations of the two assets and as such a portfolio's risk is unchanged with the addition of assets with the same risk parameters.
answerFeedback.130ec324-4827-4a1b-845d-205196d54c55: Incorrect because when two assets in a portfolio are uncorrelated or , ρ12 = 0 the portfolio's standard deviation is:  σp = ω21σ21 +ω22σ22 which is less than the weighted average of the securities' standard deviations.
answerFeedback.229d95f4-a398-44d1-9f67-9786ca3848f9:
Incorrect because when two assets in a portfolio are perfectly negatively correlated or ρ12 = –1, the portfolio's standard deviation is:

σp = ω21σ21 +ω22σ22 - 2ω1ω2σ1σ2

which is less than the weighted average of the securities' standard deviations.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516115
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely associated with secondary capital markets?

answerFeedback.6dff9146-71b2-4e1e-9830-3e68d9525eb8: Correct. A secondary market is where investors continue to trade the securities among themselves. Continuous trading is typically associated with secondary capital markets.
answerFeedback.b721166d-a026-4c8f-993b-9fe5e9184a3d: Incorrect. Book building is associated with primary markets.
answerFeedback.c7db5763-6800-41ec-8248-65f5f1527e9a: Incorrect. Lead underwriter is associated with primary markets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-PM-Y.Zhang-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following sections of the IPS most likely explains how to respond to various contingencies?

answerFeedback.63d34bbc-c52c-43f0-be2d-1fe54b1c82f1: Incorrect because this evaluation and review section provides guidance on obtaining feedback on investment results.
answerFeedback.b67ffec8-77bd-4a79-9dbe-5336ca41386e: Correct because the procedures section explains the steps to take to keep the IPS current and the procedures to follow to respond to various contingencies.
answerFeedback.c4da3535-0a0c-498c-ae27-dea440e25b56: Incorrect because the investment guidelines section provides information about how policy should be executed and on specific types of assets excluded from investment, if any.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516104
entry.itemBody: If a test rejects the hypothesis that market prices reflect private information but does not reject the hypothesis that they reflect past market data and public information, then the form of market efficiency is best described as:

answerFeedback.56c7afbe-a73f-4659-b723-9bad90506983: Incorrect because markets are strong-form efficient when market prices reflect past market data, public information, and private information.
answerFeedback.9692aeeb-71b7-4266-8c46-4bc8da63f16e:
Correct because the forms of market efficiency are as follows:

  Market Prices Reflect:
Forms of Market Efficiency Past Market Data Public Information Private Information
Weak ✓    
Semi-strong ✓ ✓  
Strong ✓ ✓ ✓

If a test rejects the hypothesis that market prices reflect private information but does not reject the hypothesis that they reflect past market data and public information, then there is evidence that the form of market efficiency is semi-strong (because only past market data and public information are reflected in market prices).
answerFeedback.ce9b83cb-8e20-4985-9eed-35d493dbdae6: Incorrect because markets are weak-form efficient when market prices reflect past market data only.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-PM-Y.Zhang-10
entry.itemBody: In order to take advantage of short-term capital market expectations, a fund manager holds less of her portfolio in equities than the policy weights prescribe. This action is best described as:

answerFeedback.2e3e8c6b-10a0-42c9-880a-b54b9f55e101: Incorrect because rebalancing refers to the process of restoring the portfolio’s original exposures to systematic risk factors. However, the action here is to choose portfolio weightings that deviate from the original exposure, which is tactical asset allocation, not rebalancing.
answerFeedback.6a00b6e1-95cf-424a-834d-956d8b7fd7c5: Correct because tactical asset allocation is the decision to deliberately deviate (e.g., reduce the weight of equities) from the policy exposures to systematic risk factors (i.e., the policy weights of asset classes) with the intent to add value based on forecasts of the near-term returns of those asset classes.
answerFeedback.f50bfe07-41d0-4c0a-8954-e26b01212543: Incorrect because security selection is an attempt to generate higher returns than the asset class benchmark by selecting securities with a higher expected return. The action to reduce the weight of equities does not involve the selection of specific securities. It is tactical asset allocation, not security selection, that chooses asset class weights that deviate from the policy.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Eichenberger-05
entry.itemBody:
An investor collects the following information about a put option:

 

Stock price at initiation $110
Strike price $105
Option premium $4.50

 

At expiration, if the price of the stock is $100, the investor's profit from selling the put is:

answerFeedback.99f944ab-b88e-4ed0-89cf-6086c743b319: Incorrect because the profit for the put seller (Π) is not equal to Max(0,X – ST) + p0 , where ST  is the price of the underlying at expiration, X is the strike price and p0 is the option premium. Therefore, the incorrect calculation yields: $9.5 = Max(0,$105 – $100) + $4.5. Instead, the correct formula is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0 (profit to the put seller) which yields: –$0.5 = –Max(0,$105 – $100) + $4.5.
answerFeedback.bf26daf3-4641-42c8-9d8b-05b520856743: Correct because Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0 (profit to the put seller), where ST  is the price of the underlying at expiration, X is the strike price and p0 is the option premium. Therefore, the correct calculation yields: –$0.5 = –Max(0,$105 – $100) + $4.5.
answerFeedback.f3265c97-1fb3-4e6d-94a5-21864b85df21: Incorrect because the profit for the put seller is not equal to p0, the option premium earned, or $4.5, since the put option expires in the money. Instead, the correct formula is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0 (profit to the put seller), where ST  is the price of the underlying at expiration, X is the strike price and p0 is the option premium. Therefore, the correct calculation yields: –$0.5 = –Max(0,$105 – $100) + $4.5.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Moustra-05
entry.itemBody: A Eurodollar bond is:

answerFeedback.0e54febb-b997-413d-8b2a-9d99cec4594d: Incorrect because Eurobonds denominated in US dollars cannot be sold to US investors at the time of issue because they are not registered with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).
answerFeedback.2d3f0f48-b4e7-4ff5-971f-b4c3a9232907: Correct because Eurodollar bonds are denominated in US dollars.
answerFeedback.eeb6547b-3f33-461e-b0fc-7be04cb674ba:
Incorrect because Eurobonds are issued outside the jurisdiction of any single country. They are underwritten by an international syndicate—that is, a group of financial institutions from different jurisdictions—and mostly sold to investors in
Europe, the Middle East, and Asia.

choices.itemBody: B. sold to US investors at issuance.
C. underwritten by a syndicate of US-based banks.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B PM 01SPH
entry.itemBody: When markets are operating normally, the portfolio approach to investing most likely:

answerFeedback.0271ed67-1122-4672-91fd-e55f0de30807: Incorrect because the expected return of a portfolio should not be higher or lower as compared to holding one randomly selected stock.
answerFeedback.d0a4cabf-c278-4483-be58-f4fc5add85d5: Incorrect because although portfolio diversification generally does reduce risk, it does not necessarily provide the same level of risk reduction during times of severe market turmoil as it does when the economy and markets are operating "normally".
answerFeedback.e5525fa6-0496-4642-b501-9977708baad9: Correct because the portfolio approach provides investors with a way to reduce the risk associated with their wealth without necessarily decreasing their expected rate of return.

choices.itemBody: A. affects an investor’s risk more than the investor’s return.
B. provides the same level of risk reduction as during times of severe market turmoil.
C. increases an investor’s expected return as compared to owning one individual stock.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10938
entry.itemBody: Which of the following components of an IPS most likely states a client's requirements for withdrawing funds from the portfolio?

answerFeedback.0faa0f1e-eb1c-4bbb-8a33-21870b9fdc17: Correct because the IPS should state what the likely requirements are to withdraw funds from the portfolio. When the client does have such a requirement, the manager should allocate part of the portfolio to cover the liability. This is a liquidity constraint that would be reflected in the investment constraints component of the IPS. Major types of constraints on portfolio selection are liquidity, time horizon, tax concerns, legal and regulatory factors, and unique circumstances. These constraints are typically discussed in a section of the IPS called, Investment Constraints. This section presents the factors that constrain the client in seeking to achieve the investment objectives.
answerFeedback.779062c4-f67e-4e1f-aefc-8ccd33c413c5: Incorrect because the Statement of Purpose section states the purpose of the IPS, and not the specific requirements of the clients.
answerFeedback.c7b16a04-2cc9-47da-8422-79bdd3434806: Incorrect because the Statement of Duties and Responsibilities section details the duties and responsibilities of the client, the custodian of the client's assets, and the investment managers, and not the specific requirements of the clients.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Equity-McDonald-16
entry.itemBody: The FCFE model:

answerFeedback.7f19cfeb-1cea-41cc-b906-5248eaa80b68: Correct because analysts may also use FCFE valuation models for a non-dividend-paying stock.
answerFeedback.bdab1af5-8e40-4635-804c-7d6bacc13f99: Incorrect because the calculation of FCFE starts with the calculation of cash flow from operations (CFO). CFO is simply defined as net income plus non-cash expenses minus investment in working capital. Cash expenses are included in net income but non-cash expenses are added back in calculating CFO.
answerFeedback.f0d992b3-c32b-47ab-99aa-4485c5a33c68: Incorrect because in practice, many analysts prefer to use a free-cash-flow-to-equity (FCFE) valuation model. These analysts assume that dividend-paying capacity should be reflected in the cash flow estimates rather than expected dividends. FCFE is a measure of dividend-paying capacity.

choices.itemBody: A. requires an estimate of future dividend payments.
B. can be used to value non-dividend paying stocks.
C. treats non-cash expense in the same manner as cash expense.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607018
entry.itemBody: A 5-year option-free bond is priced at a discount to par value. Assuming the discount rate and other key variables do not change, one year from now the value of the bond will most likely:

answerFeedback.5aa40bd7-5b5a-474e-9ca5-8244eabcbc76: Correct because the bond is priced below its par value but will be worth exactly par value at maturity. Over time, assuming a stable discount rate, the value of the bond must increase so that it is equal to par at maturity. That is, the price is “pulled to par.”
answerFeedback.9cddd51b-ff50-4adc-9f92-87198f852d9b: Incorrect because the bond’s value must increase over time to be equal to its par value.
answerFeedback.eb6abff6-781c-4a77-bfc6-ff849e4c9c27: Incorrect because the bond’s value must increase over time to be equal to its par value.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Burke-08
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is categorized as a social infrastructure asset?

answerFeedback.50093ddc-5d6a-4d5a-8b46-831e29abaaaf: Correct because social infrastructure assets are directed toward human activities and include such assets as educational, health care, social housing, and correctional facilities, with the focus on providing, operating, and maintaining the asset infrastructure.
answerFeedback.507ce8f9-2d14-446a-8764-6417d01aa85a: Incorrect because a telecommunication tower is an information and communications technology (ICT) asset and ICT assets are classified as economic (not social) infrastructure assets.
answerFeedback.8286df44-77d3-429f-bb57-b15a97364ce9: Incorrect because an airport is a transportation asset and transportation assets are classified as economic (not social) infrastructure assets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Loo-14
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, commodity forward prices will increase as a result of a decrease in the:

answerFeedback.780742ec-4354-4206-bc39-c3020ce2d9c4: Incorrect because all else being equal, a decreased risk-free rate will decrease the forward price, not increase it. The difference in prices between the cash or spot markets and derivative markets is equal to the cost of carry, which is the opportunity cost of holding these assets, and mirrors the risk-free rate and the cost of storing, transporting, and insuring the commodity. The holder of the physical commodity should expect to be compensated via a higher forward price, F0+(T), than the prevailing cash price.
answerFeedback.7be0e6da-6e71-4f3b-b4ef-9b64d506a53a: Incorrect because all else being equal, decreased storage costs will decrease the forward price, not increase it. The difference in prices between the cash or spot markets and derivative markets is equal to the cost of carry, which is the opportunity cost of holding these assets, and mirrors the risk-free rate and the cost of storing, transporting, and insuring the commodity. The holder of the physical commodity should expect to be compensated via a higher forward price, F0+(T), than the prevailing cash price.
answerFeedback.cf185fec-ec2d-4e8e-9e2c-d8e58bfcac5e: Correct because since convenience yield is a benefit and accrues to the owner, it reduces the forward price. Thus, a decrease in convenience yield will increase the forward price.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Barker-06
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following credit measures for two companies and their industry: 

Credit Ratio Company 1 Company 2 Industry
Operating profit margin 13.7% 12.1% 11.8%
Debt/EBITDA 1.21x 2.89x 3.00x
EBITDA/interest expense 15.6x 6.9x 6.9x

 

Using these ratios, credit quality is strongest for:

answerFeedback.16f60da2-4c2f-42ff-83d4-9e6ac98fdc1c: Incorrect because, compared to Company 1, Company 2 has worse ratios for EBITDA/interest expense and for Debt/EBITDA.
answerFeedback.202b261e-7307-4f24-81ed-74c0309ef8bd: Incorrect because, compared to Company 1, the industry has worse ratios for EBITDA/interest expense and for Debt/EBITDA.
answerFeedback.5fd729b4-d822-49c3-b4e4-21f57518a6a9:
Correct because Company 1 has the best ratios for both EBITDA/interest expense (highest) and for Debt/EBITDA (lowest). Therefore, Company 1 has the strongest credit quality overall. 

EBITDA/Interest expense: This ratio measures the degree to which operating profit covers periodic interest payments, with a higher coverage ratio representing less credit risk. In some cases, the numerator is changed to include depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) as well as rental expense (EBITDAR), while the denominator may be increased to include lease payments or reduced by interest earned on marketable securities and cash.

Debt to EBITDA: Leverage ratios are often expressed with debt either in the numerator or denominator, so care must be taken to reflect whether a greater or lesser number reflects increased leverage. For example, a higher debt-to-EBITDA ratio represents higher leverage, and debt may be adjusted to reflect operating leases or off-balance-sheet commitments. Rating agencies often use it as a trigger for rating actions, and banks reference it in loan covenants. A higher ratio indicates more leverage and thus higher credit risk. Note that this ratio can be very volatile for companies with high cash flow variability, such as those in cyclical industries and with high operating leverage (fixed costs).

Company 1 has the best ratios for both EBITDA/interest expense (highest) and for Debt/EBITDA (lowest). Therefore, Company 1 has the strongest credit quality overall.

entry.title: ITEM_20170421133
entry.itemBody: The bond equivalent yield for a semiannual pay bond is most likely:

answerFeedback.1f4a0991-b631-485b-8bfd-3eb28d931934: Incorrect because the bond equivalent yield for a semi-annual pay bond is equal to double the semiannual yield to maturity and is lower than the effective annual yield.
answerFeedback.c0a94522-74e2-474e-b61a-e34332b55ea3: Correct because an annual rate having a periodicity of two is known as a semiannual bond basis yield, or semiannual bond equivalent yield. Therefore, a semiannual bond basis yield is the yield per semiannual period times 2.
answerFeedback.c2bea57c-3581-434b-bfcd-079b6a28e5b7: Incorrect because the bond equivalent yield for a semi-annual pay bond is equal to double the semiannual yield to maturity and is lower than the effective annual yield.

choices.itemBody: A. equal to the effective annual yield.
B. more than the effective annual yield.
C. equal to double the yield per semiannual period.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607144
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is least likely a feature of a credit card receivable asset-backed security (ABS)?

answerFeedback.616f0ff7-7cad-4710-a7ef-8013fee097e3: Correct because a credit card receivable ABS is an example of an ABS with a non-amortizing collateral.
answerFeedback.ab56f06c-ecaa-4fee-b8db-921c1ed05079: Incorrect because a credit card receivable ABS may require early amortization of the principal if certain events occur. Such an early amortization provision would safeguard the credit quality of the issue.
answerFeedback.b27d0b7a-0753-4701-b646-cf5505807a07: Incorrect because a credit card receivable ABS would typically have a lockout period during which the cash flow that is paid out to security holders is based only on finance charges collected and fees.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02546
entry.itemBody: Prior to expiration, an at-the-money option most likely trades:

answerFeedback.72008f2d-07fb-4a66-967d-28b05b216334: Incorrect because the price of an at-the-money option prior to expiration is above the option's intrinsic value, as described in the justification for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.cb88b809-112b-41d6-8d80-f7ddad4a9f60: Incorrect because the price of an at-the-money option prior to expiration is above the option's intrinsic value, as described in the justification for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.e86f42c8-57ac-4528-a74b-67054972eefd: Correct because the value of a European call at expiration is also sometimes referred to as the exercise value or intrinsic value. When the underlying is precisely at the exercise price, the option is said to be at-the-money.  American options possess every characteristic of European options and one additional trait: they can be exercised at any time prior to expiration. Early exercise cannot be required, so the right to exercise early cannot have negative value. Thus, American options cannot sell for less than European options. Therefore, for a European or American call or a put option that is at-the-money, the relationship between value or trading price of the option and time is positive, which means that the option has a value or price that exceeds the intrinsic value.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05127
entry.itemBody: The weighted average of the time to receipt of a bond's promised future payments is best measured by:

answerFeedback.00782964-49d6-4614-9b6b-3bd053c06259: Incorrect because modified duration provides an estimate of the percentage price change for a bond given a change in its yield-to-maturity; it provides a linear estimate of the percentage price change.
answerFeedback.064eb278-0aec-48af-9634-a9515ca24379: Incorrect because the effective duration of a bond is the sensitivity of the bond's price to a change in a benchmark yield curve, not to the change in the bond's own yield-to-maturity. Effective duration is a curve duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a change in the benchmark yield curve (ΔCurve).
answerFeedback.c500f7b9-fd16-4ac6-a921-04222c559125: Correct because Macaulay duration is a weighted average of the time to receipt of the bond's promised payments, where the weights are the shares of the full price that correspond to each of the bond's promised future payments. Macaulay duration is measured in terms of time periods, not in terms of a percentage price change.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Lee-06
entry.itemBody: Convenience yield is best described as the:

answerFeedback.1d76ae89-8ddd-409c-b1e7-b8826e69e503: Incorrect because the net of the costs and benefits is often referred to by the term carry, or sometimes cost of carry. By contrast, convenience yield represents a nonmonetary advantage of holding the asset.
answerFeedback.42f0efc8-5704-41bb-a814-e090c931cbd5: Correct because convenience yield represents a nonmonetary advantage of holding the asset.
